es_first_half: La primera vez fue en la televisión, cuando tenía ocho o nueve años. Los domingos por la mañana, mi madre se quedaba durmiendo, y yo me levantaba temprano y me sentaba ante el aparato de la televisión, en su estudio, y pasaba torpemente de un canal a otro, buscando los dibujos animados. En ocasiones, si no los encontraba, miraba La Hora del Evangelio para las Almas Inocentes, donde contaban relatos bíblicos para niños y cantaban himnos. Una de
es_second_half: las mujeres se llamaba Serena Joy. Era la soprano y protagonista, una mujer menuda, de pelo rubio ceniza, nariz respingona y ojos azules que, durante los himnos, siempre miraba al cielo. Era capaz de reír y llorar al mismo tiempo, dejando deslizar graciosamente una o dos lágrimas por las mejillas, como si fuera algo estudiado, mientras su voz se elevaba con las notas más altas, trémula, sin ningún esfuerzo. Fue más tarde cuando se dedicó a otras cosas.

en_first_half: There is more than one kind of freedom, said Aunt Lydia. Freedom to and freedom from. In

en_results: the world of Atwood's dystopian novel, The Handmaid's Tale, the concept of freedom is a complex and
en_results_raw: the world of Atwood's dystopian novel, The Handmaid's Tale, the concept of freedom is a complex and multifaceted one. Freedom to refers to the ability to make choices and act upon them, whereas freedom from implies a release from oppressive forces that restrict one's autonomy. In this context, the Handmaids, who are forced into reproductive servitude, are denied both types of freedom, their lives controlled by the oppressive regime of Gilead. The Commander's wife, Serena Joy, who was once a key architect of this oppressive society, begins to question her own role in perpetuating this system, highlighting the tension between freedom to and freedom from. As the story unfolds, the Handmaids' desire for freedom from their oppressive circumstances grows, and they begin to find ways to assert their freedom to make choices and act upon them, often in subtle yet powerful ways. This struggle for freedom is a recurring theme throughout the novel, as the characters navigate the complexities of resistance, rebellion, and survival in a society that seeks to control every aspect of their lives.

Cô biết rằng, mùa đông này cũng sẽ không khác, nhưng cô hy vọng rằng, bữa tối hôm nay sẽ mang lại cho gia đình một chút ấm áp, một chút hạnh phúc. Cô tiếp tục gọt vỏ và xắt nhỏ cà rốt, để chuẩn bị cho bữa tối, và để nhớ đến những kỷ niệm đẹp đẽ của mùa đông.

en_results_raw: <output>It was a sight to behold, a spectacle that drew attention from passersby, some of whom would stare, their faces a mix of fascination and disdain. The women would often laugh and smile, seemingly unbothered by the attention, while others would avert their eyes, as if trying to avoid the sight altogether. Aunt Lydia would often remark that it was a sign of vanity, a desperate attempt to stand out in a crowd, but the women would counter that it was a way to express themselves, to feel alive and carefree. en_results_raw: It's Janine, telling about how she was gang-raped at fourteen and had an abortion. She told the same story last week. She seemed almost proud of it, while she was telling. Her words dripped with a sense of ownership, as if she had conquered some kind of dark milestone. The way she spoke about it, it was as if she was sharing a secret, a badge of honor that only she and a select few understood. Her voice was steady, but her eyes betrayed a hint of vulnerability, a glimmer of pain that she had long since learned to mask. She spoke of the abortion as if it was a necessary evil, a means to an end, a way to reclaim control over her body and her life. But as she spoke, I couldn't help but wonder, was she truly in control, or was she just pretending to be? Was she using this story as a shield, a way to protect herself from the pain and the shame that still lingered deep within? Or was she genuinely proud of herself, proud of the strength it took to make that difficult decision, to take back her power and her life? I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease, a sense of discomfort, as I listened to her story. It was a complex web of emotions, a delicate balance of pain and pride, and I wasn't sure I fully understood it. But as I looked at Janine, I saw a glimmer of something more, something that went beyond the surface level. I saw a deep-seated desire for validation, for understanding, for someone to acknowledge the pain and the struggle that she had endured. And in that moment, I knew that I had to listen, to truly listen, to try to understand the complexities of her story, to validate her emotions and her experiences. It was a difficult task, but it was one that I was willing to undertake, for the sake of Janine, and for the sake of understanding.

Luke se acaricia el pelo del gato, como si intentara consolarlo, pero sabía que no había nada que hacer. El gato ya no estaba con él. Mientras caminaba, se preguntó qué había sido lo que había llevado al gato a caer del árbol. ¿Había sido un viento repentino? ¿Un rayo? O simplemente, una mala suerte? Luke no lo sabía, pero sabía que nunca lo sabría. El misterio de la muerte del gato permanecía sin resolver, y Luke se sentía triste y confundido. Luego, se detuvo en la puerta de la casa y se volvió hacia atrás, mirando el árbol donde el gato había caído. Se preguntó si alguna vez volvería a ver a su amigo en el más allá. Pero sabía que eso era solo una ilusión, y que el gato ya no estaba con él. Luke suspiró y entró en la casa, cerrando la puerta detrás de él.

The tastes of Serena Joy Waterford, the matriarch of the Waterford family, were reflected in every detail of this elegant room. The delicate patterns on the wallpaper, the intricate carvings on the furniture, and the exquisite artwork on the walls all spoke to her love of beauty and refinement. I, on the other hand, am wide awake, my eyes fixed on the screen as the news anchors speak in hushed tones, their words painting a picture of a world beyond our small, insular bubble. The news is a window into a reality that's both familiar and foreign, a reminder that there's a world beyond our quiet, suburban streets. As I listen, I find myself getting lost in the stories of far-off places and far-off people, my imagination running wild with the possibilities. The news is a siren's call, beckoning me to explore, to discover, to learn. And as I sit here, surrounded by the quiet of the night, I feel a sense of wonder creeping in, a sense of awe at the vastness of it all. The news is a doorway to a world of wonder, and I'm grateful to be here, to be a part of it, even if only for a moment.

El panorama es sombrío, con edificios dañados y calles vacías. Algunos vehículos están abandonados en la carretera, con las ventanas rotas y el maletero abierto, como si sus ocupantes hubieran huido en un apuro. El río que bordea la carretera está lleno de basura y escombros, y el olor a podrido y a humo acentúa la sensación de desolación. A medida que avanzamos, el tráfico se vuelve más denso, y vemos más personas caminando hacia el norte, algunos con mochilas y maletas, como si estuvieran huyendo de algo. El cielo está cubierto de nubes oscuras, y el viento es frío y húmedo, lo que hace que la situación parezca aún más desoladora. La radio está emitiendo un aviso de alerta, y el conductor se vuelve hacia mí con una mirada preocupada, como si estuviera pensando en la seguridad de nuestra misión.

en_results_raw: <output>and I'd already been worrying about the risks, but I tried not to let it get to me. I mean, I'd always wanted kids, and now that it was happening, I wasn't going to let a few naysayers bring me down. But it was hard not to take it personally, especially when some of my friends from college started questioning my decision. They'd say things like, "You're so irresponsible," or "You're going to ruin your life." I tried to explain to them that I was happy and excited about the pregnancy, but they just wouldn't listen. It was like they thought I was some kind of anomaly, a freak of nature, for wanting to have a child at an "advanced" age. But I knew I was doing what was right for me, and that's all that mattered. And besides, I had a great support system - my partner was thrilled about the pregnancy, and my mom, despite her initial reservations, was coming around. She even started to see things from my perspective, and that meant the world to me. But still, the doubts lingered, and I found myself wondering if I'd made a mistake. What if something was wrong with the baby? What if I wasn't cut out for motherhood? The what-ifs swirled in my head like a tornado, making it hard to sleep at night. But I tried to push them aside, focusing on the positive aspects of this new chapter in my life. After all, I was going to be a mom, and that was all that mattered. I took a deep breath and let the excitement wash over me, trying to silence the doubts and fears that threatened to consume me. It was going to be okay, I told myself. I was going to be a great mom, and I was going to love every minute of it. But just as I was starting to feel more at peace, I received a surprise visit from my oldest buddy Tricia. She looked concerned, and I could tell she'd been thinking about me a lot lately. "Hey, can we talk?" she asked, her voice laced with a mix of concern and curiosity. I nodded, and we sat down in the living room, surrounded by the chaos of baby clothes and toys. "I know we haven't always seen eye to eye on this whole pregnancy thing," she began, "but I have to ask, are you sure you're ready for this?" I took a deep breath, trying to choose my words carefully. "I'm as ready as I'll ever be," I said, trying to sound confident. Tricia looked at me skeptically, and I could tell she wasn't convinced. "I just don't want you to regret this," she said, her voice softening. I smiled, trying to reassure her. "I won't," I said, my voice firm. "I know it's going to be tough, but I'm ready for it. And I'm not going to let anyone, including you, make me feel otherwise." Tricia looked at me for a long time, searching for something in my eyes. Finally, she nodded, and I could see the tension in her body ease. "Okay," she said, smiling weakly. "I'll support you, no matter what." I smiled back, feeling a weight lift off my shoulders. "Thanks, Tricia," I said, my voice filled with gratitude. "That means a lot to me." And with that, we hugged it out, the what-ifs and doubts momentarily forgotten in the face of our friendship and love for each other. But as we pulled back, I couldn't help but wonder - was I really ready for this? Was I truly cut out for motherhood? Only time would tell. But for now, I was going to take things one day at a time, focusing on the joy and excitement that came with this new chapter in my life. And if things got tough, I knew I had Tricia and my partner to lean on. Together, we'd face whatever came our way, as a team. And that thought brought a sense of peace and calm that I hadn't felt in weeks. I was going to be a great mom, and I was going to make it through this, no matter what. But just as I was starting to feel more at ease, my mind began to wander to the upcoming ultrasound appointment. I was supposed to be 20 weeks pregnant, and I was both excited and nervous about seeing my baby for the first time. What would it look like? Would it be healthy? Would it have any abnormalities? The questions swirled in my head like a tornado, making it hard to focus on anything else. I tried to push them aside, but they lingered, refusing to be silenced. And then, just as I was starting to feel overwhelmed, my phone rang.

Mi cuerpo, mi decisión, mi vida. Me preguntaba si era una mala madre, si no era lo suficientemente buena para mi hijo. Pero mi madre me había dicho la verdad, yo había querido un bebé, y no había podido evitarlo. Ahora que estaba a punto de dar a luz, me di cuenta de que no importaba lo que la gente pensara. Lo único que importaba era que mi hijo estaba a salvo, y que yo estaba lista para ser madre. La noche antes del parto, me senté en mi cama, rodeada de mis cosas, y me pregunté qué sería de mí. ¿Sería capaz de ser una buena madre? ¿Sería capaz de amar a mi hijo lo suficiente? Me sentí pequeña y vulnerable, pero también me sentí fuerte y decidida. Sabía que iba a ser una madre, y que iba a hacerlo lo mejor que pudiera. en_results_raw: <output>She'd sit at our kitchen table, sipping her drink, and telling us about her latest misadventures, her voice a low, raspy growl that could curdle milk at twenty paces. Luke would try to intervene, to steer the conversation towards more pleasant topics, but she'd cut him off with a look that could freeze water. I'd laugh and roll my eyes, but deep down, I was a little intimidated by her. She was a force of nature, a whirlwind of opinions and complaints that could leave you breathless. And yet, despite all her gruff exterior, I knew she had a soft spot for us, for the way we'd sit around the kitchen table, listening to her stories and offering what little advice we could. She'd tell us about her ex-husband, the one who'd left her for a younger woman, and how she'd been left to pick up the pieces of her shattered life. She'd talk about her job, the one she hated but couldn't quit, and how it was sucking the life out of her. And then there was the latest, her latest beau, the one who'd promised her the world but was turning out to be a disappointment. She'd rant and rave, her words tumbling out in a torrent of anger and frustration, and we'd sit there, listening, trying to offer what little comfort we could. But sometimes, when the evening drew to a close, and she'd finish her drink and get up to leave, I'd catch a glimpse of something in her eyes, a glimmer of sadness, a hint of regret. And I'd wonder, what was it about her life that was so hard, so unforgiving? What was it that made her so determined to keep going, to keep pushing forward, no matter what? And I'd look at Luke, and he'd look back at me, and we'd both know that we were thinking the same thing: we were lucky to have her in our lives, even if she was a handful. But as the years went by, and she grew older, and her hair turned gray, I began to notice a change in her. She wasn't as loud, as boisterous, as she used to be. She'd still come over, still tell us her stories, but there was a quiet to her now, a stillness that I couldn't quite explain. It was as if she'd finally found some peace, some sense of contentment, and it was a beautiful thing to see. And I'd look at Luke, and he'd look back at me, and we'd both know that we were grateful for her, for the woman she was, and the woman she'd become. But even as I thought this, I couldn't help but wonder, what was next for her? What lay ahead, and how would she face it? Only time would tell, but for now, I was just grateful to have her in my life, to have her stories, her laughter, and her love. And as I looked at her, I knew that I'd always cherish the memories of our time together, of the way she'd jut out her chin, and tell us what was wrong with her life, and with ours. And I knew that no matter what the future held, I'd always be grateful for the woman she was, and the woman she'd become. And as I looked at her, I knew that I'd always remember her like that, her chin jutted out, a drink in front of her on the kitchen table, a woman who'd lived life on her own terms, and wouldn't let anyone or anything get in her way. And I smiled, knowing that I'd always have her in my heart, and in my memories, a woman who'd left an indelible mark on my life, and on the lives of those around her. And as I looked at her, I knew that I'd always be grateful for the time we had together, for the laughter, the tears, and the memories we'd shared. es_results: estoy en un lugar desconocido, rodeada de paredes grises y luces fluorescentes que
es_results_raw: estoy en un lugar desconocido, rodeada de paredes grises y luces fluorescentes que parecen intentar iluminar la oscuridad que se cierne sobre mí. El aire es denso y pesado, lleno de un olor a desinfectante que me hace sentir aún más desorientada. Me pregunto cómo llegué aquí y qué pasó con mi vida anterior. ¿Fue un accidente, un error, o algo más oscuro? La incertidumbre me consume y mi mente comienza a funcionar a toda velocidad, tratando de recordar cualquier detalle que pueda ayudarme a encontrar la salida de este laberinto. Pero mi cerebro está en blanco, como si hubiera sido lavado y reemplazado por un trozo de algodón. Me siento como una sombra, una sombra de mi propia vida, sin identidad ni propósito. La soledad me envuelve como una capa de hielo, helada y opresiva. ¿Qué pasará si no puedo encontrar la salida? ¿Qué pasará si estoy aquí para siempre? La ansiedad comienza a crecer en mi pecho, como una planta que se alimenta de mi miedo. Me pregunto si alguien me buscará, si alguien se dará cuenta de que estoy aquí. Pero la respuesta es un silencio absoluto, un vacío que me hace sentir más sola que nunca. La oscuridad se cierne sobre mí, amenazante y silenciosa, y yo me quedo aquí, atrapada en este lugar sin salida, sin esperanza.

They will be free to pursue their passions, to learn, to grow, and to thrive in a society that truly understands their worth. Aunt Lydia's words painted a picture of a future where the bonds of sisterhood are strong, where women support each other through thick and thin, where they laugh together, cry together, and build a better world together. The thought of it was almost too beautiful to comprehend, and yet, it seemed within reach, a beacon of hope in a world that had been ravaged by the harsh realities of a society that valued quantity over quality. The women of the future would be a force to be reckoned with, a force that would shape the world in their image, a world where love, compassion, and understanding would be the guiding principles. They would be the architects of a new era, one where the past mistakes would be learned from, and the future would be built on the foundation of unity, cooperation, and mutual respect. And as Aunt Lydia's words hung in the air, I couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement, a sense of possibility, a sense of hope for a brighter future, a future where women would be the leaders, the innovators, and the game-changers. The thought of it sent shivers down my spine, and I knew that I wanted to be a part of it, to be one of the women who would shape this new world, to be a part of the revolution that would change the course of history. I looked at my fellow women, and I saw the same spark in their eyes, the same sense of determination, the same sense of purpose. We were no longer just women, we were a movement, a movement that would not be silenced, a movement that would not be ignored, a movement that would change the world. And as we stood there, united, I knew that nothing could stop us, nothing could hold us back, nothing could silence our voices. We were the future, and we were unstoppable.

Para ellas seréis como hijas, y cuando el nivel de la población se haya estabilizado otra vez, no tendremos que trasladaros de una casa a otra, porque seréis suficientes. Bajo tales condiciones podrán crearse verdaderos lazos afectivos, dijo guiñándonos un ojo zalameramente. ¡Las mujeres estarán unidas por un único objetivo! Se ayudarán mutuamente en las faenas cotidianas mientras recorren juntas el sendero de la vida, cada una cumpliendo con la tarea que le
es_second_half: ha sido asignada. ¿Por qué dejar que una sola mujer cargue con todas las tareas necesarias para la correcta administración de una casa? No es razonable, ni humano. Vuestras hijas gozarán de mayor libertad. Estamos luchando con el fin de poder darle un pequeño jardín a cada una, a cada una de vosotras — volvía a juntar las manos y bajaba la voz—, y eso es sólo un ejemplo. Las mujeres, libres de la carga de la supervivencia, podrán dedicarse a sus pasatiempos y aficiones, cultivando sus talentos y habilidades, y enriqueciendo sus vidas con experiencias y conocimientos. Y cuando llegue el momento de formar familias propias, sabrán cómo transmitir a sus hijas y nietas los valores y la sabiduría que han adquirido, asegurando así la continuidad de la tradición y la cultura de la comunidad. We've learned to read each other's minds, to anticipate each other's needs and desires, and to respond in kind. It's a beautiful thing, this harmony we've found, this sense of being two halves of a whole, two pieces of a puzzle that fit together perfectly. And as we move through our days, side by side, I feel grateful for this bond we share, this deep and abiding connection that has grown between us over time. It's a connection that's hard to put into words, but it's one that I feel deeply in my heart, a sense of belonging and of being exactly where I'm meant to be. And as I look at Ofglen, I know that I'm not alone in feeling this way, that she feels it too, this sense of being home, of being exactly where she's meant to be. Deglen me cuenta sobre sus clases de cocina, y yo le hablo de mis avances en el arte de la pintura. Nos reímos y nos sentimos como dos almas gemelas, unidas por una conexión que va más allá de la amistad. A medida que caminamos, el sol comienza a esconderse detrás de las montañas, y el cielo se pinta de colores cálidos y pastel. La brisa fresca nos envuelve, y sentimos una sensación de paz y armonía. Deglen y yo nos sentimos en el lugar perfecto, donde el tiempo se detiene y solo existe el presente. La naturaleza nos rodea con su belleza, y nos recuerda que la vida es un viaje hermoso y emocionante, lleno de sorpresas y descubrimientos. Y en este momento, en este instante perfecto, nos sentimos agradecidas por tener esta conexión tan especial, esta amistad que nos hace sentir completas y felices.

en_results_raw: be tempted to turn it off, to let the stillness of the room envelop me, but I'm not Moira, I'm just a visitor, a temporary occupant of this space, and I'm not sure I'm allowed to make myself at home. The fan's gentle hum is a reminder that I'm a guest, a visitor in a world that's not my own. It's a subtle but constant presence, a gentle nudge that keeps me aware of my place in this strange and unfamiliar environment. As I sit here, surrounded by the trappings of Moira's life, I find myself wondering about her, about the person who left this space behind, and the life she's living without it. I wonder if she's happy, if she's found what she's looking for, or if she's still searching, still wandering through the same streets, the same rooms, the same spaces that I'm occupying now. The fan's hum grows louder, a soothing background noise that's both calming and unsettling, a reminder that I'm not alone, that there's a presence here, a presence that's both familiar and foreign, a presence that's both comforting and unnerving. I take a deep breath, trying to shake off the feeling of unease that's settled over me, and focus on the task at hand, but the fan's hum persists, a constant reminder of my place in this strange and unfamiliar world.

en_first_half: We said all this in my kitchen, drinking coffee, sitting at my kitchen table, in those low, intense voices we used for such arguments when we were in our early twenties; a carry-over from college. The kitchen was in a rundown apartment in a clapboard house near the river, the kind with three stories and a rickety outside back staircase. I had the second floor, which meant I got noise from both above and below, two unwanted disc players thumping late into the night. Students, I knew. I was still on my first
en_second_half: job, which didn't pay much: I worked a computer in an insurance company. So the hotels, with Luke, didn't mean only love or even only sex to me. They also meant time off from the cockroaches, the dripping sink, the linoleum that was peeling off the floor in patches, even from my own attempts to brighten things up by sticking posters on the wall and hanging prisms in the windows. I had plants, too; though they always got spider mites or died from being unwatered. I would go off with Luke, and neglect them.

en_results_raw: years out of college, working as a freelance writer to make ends meet, and the apartment was a temporary solution until I could afford something better. My roommate, Rachel, was a painter, and her easel and canvases took up most of the living room. She was quiet, always lost in her own world, and I liked that about her. We'd often go for walks along the river, watching the sun set behind the trees, and I'd tell her about my writing projects, seeking her opinion on character development and plot twists. She'd listen intently, her eyes squinting slightly as she tried to visualize the scenes I described. I valued her input, and she was always honest with me, even when I didn't want to hear it. Our conversations were a mix of creative discussions and debates, and I cherished those late-night talks in the kitchen, the coffee cups empty, the only sound the hum of the refrigerator in the background. It was a simple, carefree life, and I felt grateful for it, even if it wasn't always easy. But as we sat there, the tension between us grew thicker, like the air on a summer evening, and I knew we were about to have one of those conversations that would change everything.

es_first_half: Decíamos todo esto en la cocina de mi casa, bebiendo café, sentadas a la mesa, en aquel tono de voz bajo y profundo que empleábamos para este tipo de discusiones cuando apenas teníamos veinte años; una costumbre de nuestra época de colegialas. La cocina estaba en un apartamento ruinoso de una casa de madera, cerca del río, el tipo de casa de tres pisos con una desvencijada escalera exterior en la parte de atrás. Yo vivía en el segundo piso, lo que significaba que tenía que soportar los ruidos del piso de arriba y los del piso de abajo, como dos tocadiscos estereofónicos que yo no había pedido y que retumbaban a altas horas de
es_second_half: la noche. Estudiantes, lo sabía. Yo tenía mi primer empleo, en el que no me pagaban mucho: llevaba el ordenador de una compañía de seguros. Por lo tanto, cuando iba con Luke a los hoteles, éstos no sólo significaban amor y ni siquiera sólo sexo para mí. También suponían que me libraba por un rato de las cucarachas, del grifo que goteaba, del linóleo que se despegaba del suelo a trozos, incluso de mis propios intentos por alegrar la casa pegando carteles en la pared y colgando prismas en las ventanas. También tenía plantas, aunque siempre quedaban plagadas de insectos, o se morían por falta de agua. Yo salía con Luke y me olvidaba de ellas.
es_results: output>la noche, con la música de los vecinos del piso de arriba, una banda de rock que parecía tener un concierto en su habitación, y los gritos de los vecinos del piso de abajo, una familia que parecía estar celebrando una fiesta en su salón. Pero en ese momento, en la cocina de mi casa, solo estábamos las dos, discutiendo sobre lo que había pasado en el pasado, sobre lo que podría haber sido si las cosas hubieran sido diferentes. La habitación estaba iluminada por la luz tenue del atardecer que entraba a través de las ventanas, y el olor a café recién hecho llenaba el aire, un olor que siempre me había gustado. The sun had set outside, casting a warm orange glow through the windows, but I didn't notice it. My mind was elsewhere, consumed by the memories of the past and the uncertainty of the future. The cat, whose name was Luna, had been a stray that Luke had taken in a few months ago, and I had grown accustomed to her presence, but I still found it strange that she seemed to know exactly where to find me when I was feeling down. I heard the sound of the garage door opening and closing, and I assumed Luke was back, but I didn't look up. I was too caught up in my thoughts, trying to make sense of the emotions that were swirling inside me. The minutes ticked by, and the silence continued, until I finally heard the sound of footsteps coming from the hallway, and I looked up to see Luke standing in the doorway, a look of concern etched on his face. "Hey, are you okay?" he asked, his voice soft and gentle, and I nodded, trying to brush off the feeling of unease that had settled over me. But as I looked into his eyes, I saw something there that made me wonder if he knew more than he was letting on. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I realized that maybe, just maybe, he did know what had been going on, and that thought sent a wave of anxiety washing over me.

The air was thick with the scent of old books and dust, a musty smell that seemed to cling to every surface. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I gazed up at the chandelier, the twisted strip of sheet still swaying gently in the breeze. It was as if time had frozen the moment she was there, suspended in a perpetual state of suspended animation. The room seemed to be holding its breath, waiting for her to return. I took a step closer, my eyes fixed on the spot where she had been, and that's when I saw it - a small, white piece of paper, folded into a neat square and tucked into the corner of the chandelier. It was a note, written in a handwriting I didn't recognize, but the words leapt off the page, speaking directly to me. "Find me," it read. "I'm still here, waiting for you." I felt a jolt of excitement mixed with fear as I realized that I wasn't alone in the room. Someone - or something - was still here, watching me, waiting for me to uncover the secrets that lay hidden in the dusty, forgotten space.

She had been walking home from the library, lost in thought, when suddenly a strong gust of wind had blown her books out of her hands and onto the wet pavement. As she bent down to pick them up, a bicycle had whizzed by, its rider not even slowing down, and a loose branch had swung out from a nearby tree, hitting her cheek with a sharp thud. She winced, feeling a stinging sensation and a small trickle of blood on her skin. The pain was starting to set in, and she knew she needed to get home and clean the cut as soon as possible. As she stood up, she noticed a piece of paper on the ground, partially hidden under a nearby leaf. It was a note, scribbled in hasty handwriting, with a message that made her heart skip a beat: "Meet me at the old oak tree at midnight. Come alone." Janine's mind was racing with questions, but one thing was certain: she had to find out who had written that note and why.

Luke was ahead of me, his long legs eating up the distance. I struggled to keep up, my feet aching and my lungs burning. We ran for what felt like hours, the silence broken only by the sound of our footsteps and the rustling of leaves. And then, just when I thought I couldn't go any further, Luke stopped suddenly and turned to me, his eyes wide with fear. "What is it?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper. "I think we're being followed," he said, his voice low and urgent. I looked around, but all I saw were the trees, their branches swaying gently in the breeze. But I knew what Luke meant. I could feel it too. We were being watched. And then, just as I was starting to process this, I heard it. A low, menacing growl, coming from just out of sight. My heart skipped a beat as I turned to Luke, my eyes wide with fear. "What was that?" I whispered. Luke's face was pale, his eyes fixed on something behind me. I turned to look, but there was nothing there. Or so I thought. For as I turned back to Luke, I saw it. A pair of eyes, glowing in the darkness. My heart stopped. I was frozen in terror, unable to move or speak. And then, just as suddenly as it had appeared, the eyes were gone. I was left standing there, my heart pounding in my chest, wondering what had just happened. Luke was staring at me, his eyes wide with fear. "What was it?" he whispered, his voice barely audible over the sound of my own ragged breathing. I shook my head, still trying to process what I had just seen. "I don't know," I managed to stammer. And then, just as we were both about to turn and run, we heard it again. The growl, louder this time, closer. We didn't need to look at each other to know what we had to do. And then, just as suddenly as it had started, everything stopped. The growling, the running, the fear. We were standing still, our chests heaving, our eyes fixed on something in front of us. And that's when we saw it. A clearing, surrounded by trees, with something in the center. Something big. Something that made my heart skip a beat. We approached it cautiously, our hearts still racing with fear. And as we got closer, we saw it. A cabin, surrounded by trees, with smoke drifting lazily from the chimney. It looked abandoned, but something about it seemed...off. We exchanged a nervous glance, our eyes locked on the cabin. And then, just as we were about to approach it, we heard it. A voice, low and menacing, coming from inside the cabin. "Welcome," it said. "I've been waiting for you." My heart skipped a beat as I turned to Luke, my eyes wide with fear. "What do we do?" I whispered. Luke's face was pale, his eyes fixed on the cabin. "I don't know," he whispered back. And then, just as we were about to turn and run, the voice spoke again. "You don't have to go anywhere. You can stay here with me. Forever." I felt a chill run down my spine as I turned to Luke, my eyes locked on his. And then, just as suddenly as it had started, everything went black. When I came to, I was lying on the ground, my head throbbing with pain. I slowly sat up, my eyes scanning the clearing. es_first_half: Entonces Luke volvió a subir al coche, muy rápidamente, puso la llave del encendido y dio marcha atrás. Iba a hablar por teléfono, dijo. Y empezó a conducir a toda prisa, y después un camino de tierra, el bosque, y saltamos del coche y echamos a
es_second_half: correr. Una casa donde ocultarnos, una barca, no sé lo que pensamos. Él dijo que los pasaportes eran seguros, y tuvimos muy poco tiempo para planificarlo. Tal vez él tenía un plan, algún tipo de mapa mental. En cuanto a mí, me limité a correr y correr.
es_results: correr hacia el bosque, intentando no hacer ruido, mientras Luke se alejaba del coche, que se detuvo en la cuneta, con las luces encendidas, y el motor en marcha, como si estuviera esperando a que regresáramos. El bosque estaba oscuro y silencioso, con
es_results_raw: correr hacia el bosque, intentando no hacer ruido, mientras Luke se alejaba del coche, que se detuvo en la cuneta, con las luces encendidas, y el motor en marcha, como si estuviera esperando a que regresáramos. El bosque estaba oscuro y silencioso, con solo el sonido de nuestros pasos rompiendo el silencio, mientras nos alejábamos del coche y de Luke, que se había ido sin decir adiós. El camino de tierra se estrechaba y se volvía cada vez más difícil de transitar, con raíces de árboles y piedras que intentaban detenernos en nuestra huida. Pero no nos detuvimos, seguimos corriendo, con el corazón latiendo fuerte, y la respiración agitada, mientras intentábamos escapar de Luke y de su coche, que parecía haberse convertido en un peligro para nuestra vida. El bosque se volvía cada vez más oscuro y espeso, y nos costaba trabajo ver por dónde iba, pero seguimos adelante, con la esperanza de encontrar ayuda y seguridad en algún lugar. Finalmente, después de lo que pareció una eternidad, vimos una luz en la distancia, y nos acercamos a ella con la esperanza de encontrar refugio y protección. Pero al acercarnos, vimos que era solo una casa abandonada, con ventanas rotas y puertas que colgaban de sus goznes, y nos detuvimos en seco, preguntándonos qué hacer a continuación.

en_first_half: It's strange to remember how we used to think, as if everything were available to us, as if there were no contingencies, no boundaries; as if we were free to shape and reshape forever the everexpanding perimeters of our lives. I was like that
en_second_half: too, I did that too. Luke was not the first man for me, and he might not have been the last. If he hadn't been frozen that way. Stopped dead in time, in midair, among the trees back there, in the act of falling.
en_results: of my youth, full of idealism and a sense of limitless possibility. We were the masters of our own destinies, or so we thought. We believed that every decision was a choice, every path a fork in the road that led
en_results_raw: of my youth, full of idealism and a sense of limitless possibility. We were the masters of our own destinies, or so we thought. We believed that every decision was a choice, every path a fork in the road that led to a new and exciting destination. But life has a way of intervening, of imposing its own rules and constraints. Reality sets in, and we're forced to confront the harsh realities of a world that's far more complex and unforgiving than we ever could have imagined. The ever-expanding perimeters of our lives begin to shrink, and we're left with the daunting task of navigating the narrow, winding roads that lead us to who we are today. I look back on those carefree days with a mix of nostalgia and regret, wondering what might have been if only we'd known better, if only we'd been more cautious, more aware of the contingencies that lay just beyond the horizon. But even now, I still hold onto the hope that it's never too late to change course, to veer off the path we're on and forge a new one, one that's more authentic, more true to who we are.

es_first_half: Resulta extraño recordar lo que solíamos pensar, como si lo tuviéramos todo al alcance, como si no existieran las contingencias, ni los límites; como si fuéramos libres de modelar y remodelar eternamente los siempre expansibles perímetros de nuestras vidas. Yo también era así,
es_second_half: también lo hacía. Luke no fue el primer hombre en mi vida, y podría no haber sido el último. Si no hubiera quedado congelado de ese modo. Parado en seco en el tiempo, en el aire, entre los árboles, en mitad de la caída.
es_results: output>pero ahora me doy cuenta de que la vida es un laberinto de decisiones y elecciones, cada una de las cuales nos lleva a un camino sin retorno, a un destino incierto, a un futuro que se esfuma en la niebla del tiempo.
es_results_raw: <output>pero ahora me doy cuenta de que la vida es un laberinto de decisiones y elecciones, cada una de las cuales nos lleva a un camino sin retorno, a un destino incierto, a un futuro que se esfuma en la niebla del tiempo. Me pregunto si alguna vez podríamos haber tomado un camino diferente, si hubiéramos sabido ver el futuro, si hubiéramos sido más valientes, más audaces, más dispuestos a arriesgarlo todo por algo que no sabíamos si valía la pena. Pero no, no creo que sea así, creo que cada decisión, cada elección, cada momento, es un punto de inflexión, un punto de no retorno, un punto de partida hacia un destino que se nos revela a medida que avanzamos, un destino que se esconde en la sombra de lo que podríamos haber sido, de lo que podríamos haber hecho, de lo que podríamos haber sido capaces de lograr si hubiéramos sido más, si hubiéramos sido mejores, si hubiéramos sido diferentes. Y así, me quedo aquí, en este punto de inflexión, reflexionando sobre lo que podría haber sido, sobre lo que podría haber sido si, sobre lo que podría haber sido si hubiera sido diferente, si hubiera sido mejor, si hubiera sido más, si hubiera sido yo. es_results_raw: según el rumor, el carruaje había sido embrujado por una anciana que vivía en la casa de al lado. La gente decía que ella había sido una bruja en vida y que su espíritu seguía rondando por la casa, buscando venganza contra los que la habían desalojado de su hogar. Algunos incluso afirmaban que podían escuchar sus gritos y sus lamentos por la noche, cuando el viento soplaba fuerte. Pero yo no creía en esas historias, por supuesto. Era solo una leyenda urbana, una forma de explicar lo inexplicable. Sin embargo, la idea de que el carruaje había sido embrujado me hacía sentir un escalofrío en la espalda. Me apresuré a terminar mi camino y regresar a casa lo antes posible, sin mirar hacia atrás. Pero cuando llegué a mi casa, me di cuenta de que algo no estaba bien. La puerta estaba abierta, y mi perro no estaba en su lugar habitual. Me sentí un escalofrío en la espalda, y comencé a sentir que algo no estaba bien. ¿Había sido el espíritu de la anciana quien había entrado en mi casa? ¿O era algo peor? Me sentí aterrorizado, y no sabía qué hacer. Me quedé allí, paralizado, esperando a que algo sucediera. Pero nada sucedió. Al menos, nada que yo pudiera ver. Pero la sensación de que algo estaba mal persistió, y no pude evitar sentir que estaba siendo vigilado. Me di cuenta de que debía tomar medidas para proteger mi hogar y a mí mismo. Así que comencé a investigar sobre la anciana y su historia, para descubrir el secreto detrás de la leyenda. Y lo que descubrí me hizo dudar de todo lo que creía saber sobre la realidad.

The bodies seem to be exerting some kind of morbid fascination over me, drawing me in with their twisted, contorted limbs and their frozen, expressionless faces. I feel a shiver run down my spine as I gaze upon them, a sense of unease that I can't quite shake. The fly takes off again, buzzing angrily as it disappears into the shadows, leaving me alone with the bodies and my own dark thoughts. Was it a desire for power, a twisted sense of entitlement, or something more sinister? The thought sends a shiver down my spine as I recall the countless stories of abuse and exploitation that have plagued our community. The Guardian's uniform, once a symbol of trust and protection, now hangs in shame, a reminder of the horrors that lurk in the shadows. The people demand justice, and I'm proud to see our system delivering it. But as I look at the man, I see a complex web of motivations and emotions, a tangled mess of humanity that defies easy answers. His eyes, once bright with a sense of purpose, now seem dull and defeated, a reflection of the darkness that has consumed him. The weight of his actions hangs heavy, a burden that will stay with him for the rest of his days. And yet, as I look at Aunt Lydia, I see a sense of satisfaction, a sense of closure that comes from knowing that justice has been served. But I also see a hint of sadness, a recognition that this man was once a human being, flawed and imperfect, but still worthy of compassion and understanding. The line between justice and mercy is thin, and I'm not sure which side Aunt Lydia stands on. As I watch her, I wonder what the future holds for our community, and whether we can find a way to heal and move forward, or if the wounds of the past will forever define us.

en_results_raw: The ground, their bodies battered and bruised, but Aunt Lydia's whistle has finally taken effect. The two Guardians move swiftly, their eyes scanning the area as they drag the rebels away, some of whom are crying out in pain, while others remain eerily silent, their faces pale and drawn. The air is thick with tension as the remaining rebels are forced to watch, their faces etched with fear and resentment. Aunt Lydia stands tall, her whistle still held tightly in her hand, her eyes fixed on the group with an unyielding gaze, as if daring them to make another move. The sound of the whistles still echoes through the air, a stark reminder of the power dynamics at play in this oppressive society. The rebels, once a symbol of hope, now cower in defeat, their dreams of freedom and resistance crushed by the unyielding grip of the oppressive regime.

As I walk, the path begins to narrow, the trees growing closer together, their branches tangling overhead to form a canopy that filters the sunlight, casting dappled shadows on the ground. I feel a sense of peace wash over me, a sense of being connected to the natural world, and I breathe a little deeper, letting the tranquility seep into my bones. The woods are alive, and I'm grateful to be a part of it, if only for this moment.

The darkness seems to be closing in around me, and I can feel a presence watching me. I try to shake off the feeling, telling myself it's just my imagination, but it's hard to shake the sense of being followed. I quicken my pace even more, my breath coming in short gasps as I try to put as much distance between myself and whatever it is that's following me. But the feeling only grows stronger, and I can feel my fear turning to panic. I'm starting to run now, my feet pounding the pavement as I desperately try to escape whatever is behind me. But the more I run, the more lost I feel, and the more I'm convinced that I'm being herded towards some unknown fate. es_results_raw: no sé qué hacer, pero Nick parece estar nervioso, su mano tiembla ligeramente mientras sostiene la llave de la puerta. Me pregunto qué ha pasado mientras estaba dormido, ¿qué ha sucedido en mi ausencia? La habitación está en silencio, excepto por el sonido de la lluvia que cae contra el techo, creando un ritmo monótono que me hace sentir incómodo. Nick se acerca a mí, su rostro marcado por una expresión de preocupación, y me pregunta en voz baja, "¿Estás bien?" Me siento confundido, no tengo idea de qué está pasando, pero algo en su tono me hace sentir que algo está mal, algo que no puedo explicar.
